You can only add that to Retail Pro. It is disabled in PRO VL. You won't be able to upgrade to prowmc and actually activate it, even if you have the free upgrade key. MS shut down the KMS activation workaround.  First they blocked the KMS, then they blocked the workaround for data.dat swap. I believe they also blocked the phone method swap, though I haven't personally tested it.

If you actually bought Windows 8, just use my normal Jan2013 pro retail version or the one from the AIO.

nisgos, I probably could, but I won't.
If you want to have no problems with activation in Office 2013, get a VL operating system and a VL version of Office, preferably with the same processor architecture (x86, x64).

Right click the file and burn with the built-in iso burning tool that's been in windows since forever.
DVD burning programs are garbage. The one that comes with the operating systems have never failed me, ever.
I don't include kb files that aren't requested by windows update.

libertycity, read up on dism. It's been included in windows since windows 7 came out. It was basically a combination of a few tools like pkgmgr and imagex that integration gui frontends were based on.

My process is roughly as follows on the kb files.  First I do a fresh install from the rtm. Then I check windows update. I copy all the msu hotfixes from my old kbfiles folder and download any new ones I need directly from ms download center.

For the Integration I basically mount the image with dism, run the dism /add-package command pointed at my updated kbfiles folder, then unmount with the /commit.

As far as not trusting full-packs, you don't have to. Compare the sha-1 from msdn with the one you create by extracting the rars.
You do this by getting something like hashtab.
